title: How to Add a PDF to a Kindle

steps.title: Find your "Send-to-Kindle" email address.
steps.content: Find your "Send-to-Kindle" email address. This is the email address you'll use to send the PDF to your Kindle or Kindle app: [1] X Research source Open Amazon's "My Devices" page and sign in if necessary. Scroll down and click the Personal Document Settings heading. Scroll down and review the email address listed under the "E-mail address" heading. Add a new email address if needed by clicking Add a new approved e-mail address , typing in the email address when prompted, and clicking Add Address .

steps.title: Open an email inbox.
steps.content: Open an email inbox. Go to any email service with which you have an account to do so. If you aren't automatically logged into the email service, you'll need to enter your email address and password to log in.

steps.title: Create a new email.
steps.content: Create a new email. Open the "New Email" window by doing the following depending on your preferred email service: Gmail — Click COMPOSE (or, if you're using the new Gmail inbox, ＋ Compose ) on the left side of the page. Outlook — Click ＋ New message in the upper-left corner of the page. Yahoo — Click Compose in the upper-left side of the page. iCloud Mail — Click the blue "Compose" icon at the top of the page.

steps.title: Enter your "Send-to-Kindle" email address.
steps.content: Enter your "Send-to-Kindle" email address. In the "To" text field, type in the email address you found in the "E-mail address" section of your Amazon account's Kindle page.

steps.title: Click the "Attachment" icon.
steps.content: Click the "Attachment" icon. It's usually at the bottom or the top of the email page. Clicking this icon will bring up a File Explorer (Windows) or Finder (Mac) window. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Select your PDF.
steps.content: Select your PDF. Go to the location of the PDF on your computer, then click the PDF to select it.

steps.title: Click Open.
steps.content: Click Open . It's in the bottom-right corner of the window. The PDF will be attached to your email.

steps.title: Send your email.
steps.content: Send your email. Click the Send button (or paper plane-shaped icon) to do so. This will deliver the PDF to your Kindle or Kindle app, though the PDF may take a few minutes to appear. [3] X Research source Depending on your email service, you may be asked if you want to send your email without text in the "Subject" and body text fields. If so, click Yes or Send to confirm.

steps.title: Open the PDF on your Kindle.
steps.content: Open the PDF on your Kindle. Make sure your Kindle is unlocked and connected to Wi-Fi (or on cellular data), then open the "Library" section of the Kindle to view the PDF. Once the PDF appears here, you can tap it to select it. [4] X Research source If you're using the Kindle app, open it and sign in if necessary, then tap the LIBRARY tab to view a list of your Kindle's files. You can then tap the PDF's icon when it arrives.

steps.title: Don't use this method for the Kindle app.
steps.content: Don't use this method for the Kindle app. If you're trying to put a PDF on the Kindle app on your tablet, use the email method instead.

steps.title: Download and install Android File Transfer if you're on a Mac.
steps.content: Download and install Android File Transfer if you're on a Mac. Since Mac computers can't access Android file systems on their own, you'll need to install Android File Transfer to bridge the gap: Go to https://www.android.com/filetransfer/ in your Mac's web browser. Click DOWNLOAD NOW . Double-click the downloaded DMG file. Click and drag the Android File Transfer icon onto the "Applications" folder icon.

steps.title: Copy your PDF.
steps.content: Copy your PDF. Go to the location of the PDF you want to add to your Kindle, then click the PDF and press either Ctrl + C (Windows) or ⌘ Command + C (Mac).

steps.title: Connect your Kindle to your computer.
steps.content: Connect your Kindle to your computer. Plug the USB end of your Kindle's charger cable into one of your computer's USB ports, then plug the other end of the cable into your Kindle's charging port. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Open the Kindle's folder.
steps.content: Open the Kindle's folder. This step will vary depending on your computer's operating system: Windows — Open File Explorer (or press ⊞ Win + E ), then click your Kindle's name in the left-hand sidebar. You may first have to scroll down on the sidebar to see the Kindle here. Mac — Android File Transfer should open immediately. If it doesn't, open it by typing android file transfer into Spotlight and then double-clicking Android File Transfer .

steps.title: Open the Kindle's internal storage.
steps.content: Open the Kindle's internal storage. If the Kindle doesn't open to a list of folders immediately, double-click the "Internal" or "Internal Storage" folder to open it. Skip this step on a Mac.

steps.title: Find and open the "Docs" folder.
steps.content: Find and open the "Docs" folder. This is the folder in which your Kindle's files, such as PDFs and Word documents, can be stored. Double-click it to open it. If you're uploading the PDF to a classic Kindle, this folder may be entitled "Documents" instead. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Paste in your PDF.
steps.content: Paste in your PDF. Once the "Docs" folder opens, press Ctrl + V (Windows) or ⌘ Command + V (Mac) to paste the copied PDF into the folder. This will place the PDF on your Kindle.

steps.title: Eject
steps.content: Eject and remove your Kindle from the computer. After safely ejecting your Kindle, you can detach it from its cable.

steps.title: Open the PDF on your Kindle.
steps.content: Open the PDF on your Kindle. Unlock your Kindle, then open the "Library" section of the Kindle to view the PDF. Once the PDF appears here, you can select it to open it.
